qas.question: What feature was pioneered on the HMS Hermes in 1923?
What is concentrated in the small area called an island?
Other than Japanese carriers, which side of the flight deck are islands typically built on?
What was the biggest drawback to the flush deck configuration?

answers.text: management of the exhaust from the power plant

qas.question: What was a major issue in the USS Langley?
What feature was pioneered on the HMS Hermes in 1932?
What is concentrated in the large area called an island?
Other than Chinese carriers, which side of the flight deck are islands typically built on?

plausible_answers.text: management of the exhaust from the power plant

qas.question: What was the biggest advantage to the flush deck configuration?
What was a minor issue in the USS Langley?

context: <a1_0><b6_0>The superstructure of a carrier<b6_0/><a1_0/> (such as the bridge, flight control tower) are concentrated in a relatively small area called <a0_0><b5_0>an island<b5_0/><a0_0/>, a feature pioneered on the HMS Hermes in 1923. While the island is usually built on the <a2_0><b7_0>starboard<b7_0/><a2_0/> side of the fight deck, the Japanese aircraft carriers Akagi and Hiryū had their islands built on the port side. Very few carriers have been designed or built without an island. The flush deck configuration proved to have significant drawbacks, primary of which was <a3_0><b8_0>management of the exhaust from the power plant<b8_0/><a3_0/>. <a4_0><b9_0>Fumes coming across the deck<b9_0/><a4_0/> were a major issue in USS Langley. In addition, lack of an island meant difficulties managing the flight deck, performing air traffic control, a lack of radar housing placements and problems with navigating and controlling the ship itself.
